ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Lauren Louise Griffith  Lauren

Instructor: Lauren Louise Griffith  It feels very strange to be graded by a friend, and by someone who has made the same amount of progress in the same course of study as me, as opposed to a PhD student. Quite frankly, I don't like it at all. BUT, that is no reflection on Lauren, simply on the nature of the TF role. Lauren did a fine job.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I don't love the online hybrid format. It would be nice if there was more opportunity to ask the professor questions about the lecture, but since the lecture is online and the only course time is dedicated to student-led conversations, we don't really have that option.
I thought the readings were fantastic.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I liked the novels we read.
The emphasis on three different nations from different regions really highlights the breadth of Indian lifeways!

This is one of the best courses I have ever taken, I don't know where to start. For one, the instructors are phenomenal, and I loved getting to know all the other students. I find so much value in learning in a small class like this one with a mix of undergrads, FE&S, YSOA, and YDS students all in one room, with instructors who care SO much about the students and the value of teaching. The Professors should receive an award for their work. They are far more dedicated to their teaching than any other professor I'be met at Yale. I am amazed by them. Yale needs to realize that a good researcher is not necessarily a good teacher, because few professors are as great teachers as Professors Grim and Tucker, and after taking classes with Profs Grim and Tucker, I am disappointed by most of the other instructors I've had at Yale.
I enjoyed all aspects of the course, but I particularly appreciated the chance to go to the Peabody Museum.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Class discussions need to not be dominated by the same people over and over again.

My one suggestion is to have more guest speakers, please. Tisa Wenger brought in several for a course at Yale Divinity School who might be great and are somewhat local, especially an expert on the Mohawk language. Or at the very least, perhaps Professor Ned Blackhawl since he's at Yale already?

The registrar office insisted the instructors increase the workload of this course unnecessarily. This is a half credit course that nearly had the workload of a 1 credit course, which is completely due to the fault of the registrar office, because the original syllabus was much more reasonable. I have a feeling that the registrar office (whether consciously or subconsciously) insisted on these changes because the course focuses on Native American religions -- I doubt they would have been as strict with a course on Western religions. This is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale, and it deserves more respect. It would have been rigorous even without nitpicking on the part of the administration. Please have more faith in the instructors, because I want to reiterate, this is a phenomal class, and the professors are so dedicated, caring, and engaged.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: This course is phenomenally structured.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn about Native American ecology and religion.
The professors are my favorite people at Yale, they are extremely caring and dedicated.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learned a lot about many different Native American lifeways.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do your work for the week WAY ahead of time!
Do so!
Definitely take this course!
